natural problem:
Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$
natural solution: We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2^(i + j))) = 1 / 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2^(i + j))) = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: What is the sum of the series $\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} \frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "i > j"
and h1 : "j \<ge> 1"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. sum (\<lambda> j. 1 / (2 ^ (i + j))) {1..<i}) {1..} = 1 / 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "i > j"
and h1 : "j \<ge> 1"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. sum (\<lambda> j. 1 / (2 ^ (i + j))) {1..<i}) {1..} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the sum of the series where each term is $\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$, for all $i$ and $j$ such that $i > j$ and $j \geq 1$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "i > 0"
and h1 : "1 \<le> j"
and h2 : "j < i"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / (2 pow (i + j))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i > 0} = 1 / 3"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / (2 pow (i + j))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i > 0} = 1 / 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "i > 0"
and h1 : "1 \<le> j"
and h2 : "j < i"
and h3 : "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / (2 pow (i + j))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i > 0} = 1 / 3"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / (2 pow (i + j))) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i > 0} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find the sum of the series $\sum_{i>0}\sum_{1\leq j<i}\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: real
assumes h0 : "j \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "i > j"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i j. 1/2^(i + j)) {i. i > j} = 1/3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: real
assumes h0 : "j \<ge> 1"
and h1 : "i > j"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i j. 1/2^(i + j)) {i. i > j} = 1/3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: Find the sum of the series $\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$ where $i > j$ and $j \geq 1$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / (2 powr (i + j))) {1..}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / (2 powr (i + j))) {1..} = 1 / 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / (2 powr (i + j))) {1..}"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>k. 1 / (2 powr (i + j))) {1..} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Calculate the sum of the series where each term is $\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$ for all $j$ such that $1 \leq j < i$. The sum is equal to $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat and s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> s i j = 1 / 2 powr (i + j)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. sum (\<lambda> j. s i j) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i \<in> UNIV} = 1 / 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat and s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> s i j = 1 / 2 powr (i + j)"
shows  "sum (\<lambda> i. sum (\<lambda> j. s i j) {j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i}) {i. i \<in> UNIV} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a sequence $s(i,j)$ defined by $s(i,j)=\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$ for all natural numbers $j$ and $i$ where $1 \leq j < i$. What is the sum over all $i$ and $j$ of $s(i,j)$? The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat and s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> s i j = 1 / (2 powr (i + j))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1<..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. s i j) = 1 / 3"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat and s :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i j. 1 \<le> j \<and> j < i \<longrightarrow> s i j = 1 / (2 powr (i + j))"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{1<..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. s i j) = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: For all natural numbers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \leq j < i$, let $s(i,j) = \frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$. Find the sum over all $i$ from $1$ to infinity and $j$ from $1$ to $i-1$ of $s(i,j)$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{2..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2 ^ (i + j))) = 1 / 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: nat
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "(\<Sum>i\<in>{2..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2 ^ (i + j))) = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of the double series from $i=2$ to infinity and $j=1$ to $i-1$ of the terms $\frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes sum :: real
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum>i\<in>{2..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2 powr (i + j)))"
shows  "sum = 1/3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes sum :: real
assumes h0 : "sum = (\<Sum>i\<in>{2..}. \<Sum>j\<in>{1..<i}. 1 / (2 powr (i + j)))"
shows  "sum = 1/3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Find the sum of the series where each term is $\frac{1}{2^{(i + j)}}$ where $i$ ranges from 2 to infinity and $j$ ranges from 1 to $i - 1$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes i j :: real
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / 2 powr (i + j)) {1..<i}) {1..} = 1 / 3"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute
\[\sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}},\]where the sum is taken over all positive integers $i$ and $j$ such that $1 \le j < i.$ The final Answer is \frac{1}{3}
 ### Proof
 We have that \begin{align} \sum_{1 \le j < i} \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^{i + j}} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \sum_{i = j + 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^i} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \left( \frac{1}{2^{j + 1}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 2}} + \frac{1}{2^{j + 3}} + \dotsb \right) \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1/2^{j + 1}}{1 - 1/2} \\
 &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{2^j} \cdot \frac{1}{2^j} \\ &= \sum_{j = 1}^\infty \frac{1}{4^j} \\ &= \frac{1/4}{1 - 1/4} \\ &= \boxed{\frac{1}{3}}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes i j :: real
assumes h0 : "1 \<le> j"
and h1 : "j < i"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. sum (\<lambda>j. 1 / 2 powr (i + j)) {1..<i}) {1..} = 1 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Find the value of the infinite double sum $\sum_{i=1}^{\infty} \sum_{j=1}^{i-1} \frac{1}{2^{i+j}}$. The final answer is $\frac{1}{3}$.
